          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');

        window.eventsToSend = window.eventsToSend || []

          name: "page_rendering",
          timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
          value: JSON.stringify({
            time: performance?.now()
          })
        })
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Failed to push page render event:", error)

class="metadata Metadata_root__EZem9" data-cy="metadata"><h1 class="title Metadata_title__aM3nZ Heading_h1__jLBB4 Heading_heading___M8rU">CrowdCasts Monthly: You Have an Adversary Problem</h1><div class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><time dateTime="2013-10-16 14:09:38 UTC">Oct 16, 2013</time><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC Text_medium__TH6gG Text_secondary__o6d_E Likes_root__WVQ1_" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">6 likes</span><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC Text_medium__TH6gG Text_secondary__o6d_E Likes_root__WVQ1_" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">21,375<!-- --> <!-- -->views</span><button type="button" class="ai-tag unstyled-button AITag_tag__Xx37c" data-cy="ai-tag" aria-describedby="aiTag-description" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R3497d6:" popovertarget=":R3497d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R3497d6"><span class="icon description</button><div class="" id=":R3497d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R3497d6"></div></div><div class="author Author_root___6Bx5"><a data-cy="author-link" class="Author_link___lVxw ellipsis" title="CrowdStrike" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike"><div class="Avatar_root__GNWHY" style="width:24px;height:24px;line-height:24px"><img class="Avatar_image__Bbtll" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/profile-photo-CrowdStrike-48x48.jpg?cb=1523357406" alt="CrowdStrike" loading="lazy" decoding="sync"/></div><span>CrowdStrike</span></a></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_"><p data-cy="document-description">The document discusses adversary problems in cybersecurity, focusing on the identification and categorization of various adversary groups and their activities. It highlights notable adversaries, their motivations, and the tactics they utilize, such as spearphishing and lateral movement, while emphasizing the need for intelligence-driven security. The presentation also includes insights from CrowdStrike experts and encourages organizations to implement adversary-focused security practices.</p></div><button type="button" 4

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

Adversary Categorization
CATEGORIZATION| Adversary Groups

1

Tactics, Techniques, and Practices

2

Never assume relationships exist
Between indicators

3

Recognize adversaries are constantly changing

4

But RECOGNIZE they are HUMAN

CATEGORIZATION

these adversaries

New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

detection and response through improved inter-team collaboration and automation. - The original open design of the internet lacked security concerns
- Cybersecurity issues can be classified by the type of action, perpetrator, and targets
- National and international initiatives have been established to address cybersecurity including organizations like DHS, ITU, UN, and policies on standards, legal measures, and capacity building

class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Introduction to FIDO: A New Model for Authentication for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rfdalh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rfdalh7d6:" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the FIDO (Fast Identity Online) Alliance&#x27;s mission to provide a new authentication model using public key cryptography to mitigate the security risks associated with passwords. It highlights the growing data breach problem, the advantages of FIDO authentication over traditional methods, and the need for policy evolution to support modern authentication technologies. The FIDO ecosystem currently consists of over 250 organizations and aims to enhance security, privacy, and usability across digital services.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1alh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1alh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" data-cy="slideshow-title">Advanced persistent threats(APT)</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Advanced persistent threats(APT) for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rfdblh7d6:" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/NIIConsulting">Network Intelligence India</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses advanced persistent threats (APTs), which represent a significant risk to organizations&#x27; intellectual property and critical infrastructure, highlighting the necessity for effective mitigation strategies. APTs involve sophisticated and targeted hacking efforts, often starting with techniques like spear phishing, leading to complex attack lifecycles that include preparation, initial intrusion, expansion, persistence, search and exfiltration, and cleanup. The document also provides case studies of notable APT incidents, underscoring the challenges of detection and the importance of employee education and technological safeguards.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1blh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1blh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-11" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1clh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1clh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1clh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/iot-attacks-and-solutions/79173243"><span class="sr-only">IoT - It notes that by 2018, digital business will require fewer workers but more digital jobs, and the cost of business operations will be reduced by 30% through automation. It also discusses new technologies like smart homes, wearables, and connected medical devices. However, the widespread connectivity of devices introduces new security threats, as many devices have poor security and collect personal data without encryption. The document calls for more robust security measures to protect the growing internet of things.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1clh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" It defines malware as malicious software designed to damage computers without consent. The document outlines 10 main types of malware: viruses, worms, Trojans, spyware, adware, ransomware, rootkits, keyloggers, botnets, and bugs. It also describes 3 methods of malware analysis: static analysis, which examines code without executing it; dynamic analysis, which observes behavior by running malware; and threat analysis, which identifies malware families and tracks criminal infrastructure over time.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1flh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses malicious traffic on computer networks. It defines malicious traffic as any traffic anomalies caused by hardware/software failures or intentionally modified internet packets. Several types of malicious traffic are described, including scanners, worms, spam, backscatter, and denial-of-service (DOS) attacks. Methods for detecting and preventing malicious traffic involve anomaly detection techniques, signature scanning, intrusion detection systems, quality-of-service metrics, and network filters. The conclusion emphasizes the importance of security awareness to help mitigate internet misuse.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1mlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1mlh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-22" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1nlh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1nlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1nlh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/wso2.org/application-security-your-success-depends-on-it"><span class="sr-only">Application Security - Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Dark web</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Dark web for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rfdqlh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rfdqlh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rfdqlh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rfdqlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rfdqlh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/HASHMI007">Safwan Hashmi</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The dark web allows for anonymous browsing but has privacy risks. It can only be accessed through special browsers like Tor that hide a user&#x27;s identity and location. While the dark web protects anonymity, law enforcement has found ways to de-anonymize users through vulnerabilities in the Tor network or malware. Common uses of the dark web include drugs, weapons, child pornography, and hacking tools, though it also enables whistleblowing. Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin are often used for transactions on the dark web due to the anonymity provided.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1qlh7d6:" popover="auto" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/EngHasanShamroukh">Eng Hasan Shamroukh CISCO Exams Author</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses cybersecurity concepts including encryption, authentication, digital signatures, and penetration testing. It defines cybersecurity as protecting computer systems from threats. Encryption converts data into cipher text for protection. Authentication verifies identities through methods like passwords, certificates, and biometrics. Digital signatures mathematically verify the authenticity and integrity of messages. Penetration testing involves simulated cyber attacks to evaluate security. The document outlines security best practices and roles of security operations centers in monitoring for threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1slh7d6:" popover="auto" authentication model using public key cryptography to mitigate the security risks associated with passwords. It highlights the growing data breach problem, the advantages of FIDO authentication over traditional methods, and the need for policy evolution to support modern authentication technologies. class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mhm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mhm9i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/NIIConsulting">Network Intelligence India</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses advanced persistent threats (APTs), which represent a significant risk to organizations&#x27; intellectual property and critical infrastructure, highlighting the necessity for effective mitigation strategies. APTs involve sophisticated and targeted hacking efforts, often starting with techniques like spear phishing, leading to complex attack lifecycles that include preparation, initial intrusion, expansion, persistence, search and exfiltration, and cleanup. The document also provides case studies of notable APT incidents, underscoring the challenges of detection and the importance of employee education and technological safeguards.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rhm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rhm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-3" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Ri69i7d6:" popovertarget=":Ri69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Ri69i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/iot-attacks-and-solutions/79173243"><span class="sr-only">IoT - It notes that by 2018, digital business will require fewer workers but more digital jobs, and the cost of business operations will be reduced by 30% through automation. It also discusses new technologies like smart homes, wearables, and connected medical devices. However, the widespread connectivity of devices introduces new security threats, as many devices have poor security and collect personal data without encryption. The document calls for more robust security measures to protect the growing internet of things.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ri69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" It defines malware as malicious software designed to damage computers without consent. The document outlines 10 main types of malware: viruses, worms, Trojans, spyware, adware, ransomware, rootkits, keyloggers, botnets, and bugs. It also describes 3 methods of malware analysis: static analysis, which examines code without executing it; dynamic analysis, which observes behavior by running malware; and threat analysis, which identifies malware families and tracks criminal infrastructure over time.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rjm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses malicious traffic on computer networks. It defines malicious traffic as any traffic anomalies caused by hardware/software failures or intentionally modified internet packets. Several types of malicious traffic are described, including scanners, worms, spam, backscatter, and denial-of-service (DOS) attacks. Methods for detecting and preventing malicious traffic involve anomaly detection techniques, signature scanning, intrusion detection systems, quality-of-service metrics, and network filters. The conclusion emphasizes the importance of security awareness to help mitigate internet misuse.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rn69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rn69i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-14" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rnm9i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rnm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rnm9i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/wso2.org/application-security-your-success-depends-on-it"><span class="sr-only">Application Security - class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mp69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mp69i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/HASHMI007">Safwan Hashmi</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The dark web allows for anonymous browsing but has privacy risks. It can only be accessed through special browsers like Tor that hide a user&#x27;s identity and location. While the dark web protects anonymity, law enforcement has found ways to de-anonymize users through vulnerabilities in the Tor network or malware. Common uses of the dark web include drugs, weapons, child pornography, and hacking tools, though it also enables whistleblowing. Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin are often used for transactions on the dark web due to the anonymity provided.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rp69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rp69i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rpm9i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rpm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rpm9i7d6"><a SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the Center for Internet Security (CIS) controls and benchmarks, which are best practices for securing IT systems. It provides details on various configurations and recommendation levels, including base and advanced security practices, as well as comparisons of different benchmark versions and their coverage. The overview of benchmark recommendations highlights various sections such as identity management, networking, and logging with the number of scored and non-scored recommendations.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rpm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rpm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cybersecurity for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mq69i7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mq69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mq69i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mq69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mq69i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/EngHasanShamroukh">Eng Hasan Shamroukh CISCO Exams Author</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses cybersecurity concepts including encryption, authentication, digital signatures, and penetration testing. It defines cybersecurity as protecting computer systems from threats. Encryption converts data into cipher text for protection. Authentication verifies identities through methods like passwords, certificates, and biometrics. Digital signatures mathematically verify the authenticity and integrity of messages. Penetration testing involves simulated cyber attacks to evaluate security. The document outlines security best practices and roles of security operations centers in monitoring for threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rq69i7d6:" popover="auto" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes a CrowdStrike webinar on detecting advanced malware-free intrusions. It describes three speakers from CrowdStrike - Dmitri Alperovitch, Chris Scott, and Adam Meyers. The webinar then discusses how adversaries like China and various state-sponsored and criminal groups are adapting their tactics to evade detection, and how security teams must also adapt detection methods to focus on real-time monitoring rather than indicators of compromise. The webinar includes a case study of detecting a webshell attack in near real-time using CrowdStrike Falcon Host and concludes with a demonstration of its endpoint protection capabilities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rgmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rgmai7d6"></div><div class="separator class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Michael Saylor is the executive director of Cyber Defense Labs at UT Dallas. The document discusses current cyber security trends and emerging threats. Recent trends in 2013 included an increase in attacks with web and social engineering components as well as politically motivated DDoS attacks. Mobile devices and applications are increasingly being targeted, as are advanced persistent threats from groups like China&#x27;s APT1. Emerging threats discussed include the potential for increased cyber crime and terrorism from groups funded by drug cartels and foreign states. The document recommends best practices for organizations like user education, monitoring, encryption, and frequent security assessments.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rhmai7d6:" popover="auto" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CSIWorld">Scott Mills</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The FBI is tasked with protecting the US from cyber threats including cybercrime, espionage, and terrorism. The document outlines various cyber threats such as phishing schemes, botnets, and malware infections. It also describes the FBI&#x27;s response which includes investigating cases, sharing intelligence through task forces and information portals, and advising but not directly assisting victims. International cooperation is needed to address cyber threats effectively.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rj6ai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The 2012 Global Application &amp; Network Security Report reveals that many organizations are inadequately prepared for sophisticated, prolonged attacks, despite investing in preemptive security measures. A significant increase in HTTPS-based attacks and the evolution of DDoS strategies utilizing robust botnets present new challenges, as attackers exploit organizations&#x27; blind spots. Recommendations include enhancing attack resilience, training response teams, and implementing up-to-date methodologies to counter persistent threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rjmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rjmai7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-7" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rk6ai7d6:" popovertarget=":Rk6ai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rk6ai7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/trend-micro-is-your-cloud-secure/16776407"><span class="sr-only">Trend Micro - It notes that threats are becoming more challenging due to trends like cloud/virtualization, consumerization, and the actions of employees. An effective strategy uses global threat intelligence from multiple sources to detect both known and unknown threats. It advocates for network-wide detection, custom sandboxes for analysis, and automated security updates. The strategy aims to provide advanced, targeted protection while remaining simple to manage and deploy.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rk6ai7d6:" popover="auto" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Netscout Threat Intelligence report for the first half of 2018 highlights a significant rise in the frequency and scale of DDoS attacks, with approximately 2.8 million incidents reported and notable peaks exceeding 1 terabit per second. The report details how advancements in DDoS attack tools and techniques have made such attacks more accessible to a wider range of attackers, targeting a diverse array of organizations beyond traditional sectors. Furthermore, the evolving threat landscape is underscored by growing activities from nation-state actors and cybercriminals, with persistent innovations driving the complexity of these threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rlmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rlmai7d6"></div><div class="separator SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses how individuals and organizations can become unintended targets in cyber conflicts. It notes that cyber attacks often follow physical protests and tensions between countries. It provides tips on how to identify potential targeting through monitoring related physical protests, cyber attacks against similar organizations, and controversial business decisions. The document also categorizes different types of targets and their likelihood of facing short or long-term attacks. It closes by questioning if standard cyber defenses are sufficient against sophisticated, persistent threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rm6ai7d6:" popover="auto" data-cy="slideshow-title">International Cooperative: APT Hunting</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save International Cooperative: APT Hunting for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mmmai7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mmmai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mmmai7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mmmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mmmai7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/JoshuaLawtonMBA">Joshua Lawton, MBA</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses international cooperative efforts to hunt advanced persistent threats (APTs). It begins with introductions from two experts in the field and then provides information on what APTs are, realities of interacting with them, processes for target selection and interdiction, and examples of prior takedowns. The key points are that APTs are sophisticated threats that pursue objectives over long periods of time, interacting with them requires careful consideration of potential escalation, and efforts to disrupt APT operations are an ongoing challenge as the actors adapt and find new ways to achieve their goals.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rmmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rmmai7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-13" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rn6ai7d6:" popovertarget=":Rn6ai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rn6ai7d6"><a - Spam, viruses, and phishing rates from February to March 2020. Rates of spam increased while viruses and phishing decreased slightly. 

- An analysis of targeted cyber attacks which found many originate from China, Romania, and Cameroon rather than just locations of mail servers. Common targets were those in roles like directors, officials, and managers in areas like Asian policy and trade.

- The most common file types in emails were .xls, .doc, and .zip but encrypted .rar files posed the highest risk of containing malware when attached to emails.

from CrowdStrike<!-- --> <span class="BottomRecommendation_count__4HpLo">(<!-- -->20<!-- -->)</span></h3><div class="BottomRecommendationContent_root__2qm4_"><div class="mobile-recs"><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-0" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rgmbi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rgmbi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rgmbi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/state-of-endpoint-security-the-buyers-mindset/80622240"><span class="sr-only">State of Endpoint Security: The Buyers Mindset</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:0" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">State of Endpoint Security: The Buyers Mindset</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save State of Endpoint Security: The Buyers Mindset for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mgmbi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mgmbi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mgmbi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mgmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mgmbi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document presents the findings of a 2017 survey conducted by ESG and commissioned by CrowdStrike, focusing on endpoint security and the buyer mindset among IT professionals across midmarket and enterprise organizations in North America. Key insights reveal that organizations are experiencing increased cyberattacks on endpoints, are planning to enhance their endpoint security investments, and show a significant shift towards adopting managed security services and endpoint detection and response solutions. Overall, the report emphasizes the need for more effective and efficient cloud-based endpoint security strategies as organizations navigate a complex and evolving threat landscape.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rgmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rgmbi7d6"></div><div class="separator RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the need for a balanced approach to endpoint security that includes both prevention and detection. It argues that relying solely on prevention is not sufficient, as attacks will always get through, requiring detection capabilities to identify breaches. Likewise, detection alone is insufficient, as preventing attacks upfront reduces workload. The document outlines the key components needed to properly unify next-generation antivirus and endpoint detection and response, including complete visibility of endpoint activity, large-scale analysis capacity, and the ability to derive insights and indicators of attack from collected data. An integrated approach is advocated that allows prevention and detection to strengthen one another.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rlmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes the analysis of a domain generating algorithm (DGA) malware family. Key points include:

- The malware uses inline code obfuscation and encrypted strings to hide its functionality and communication domains. Researchers were able to deobfuscate the code and decrypt the strings to analyze the malware. 

- Clues in decrypted strings suggest the malware author is Romani, including references to Romani singers in template strings. 

- The malware generates domain names by concatenating two randomly selected words from a dictionary and appending &quot;.net&quot;. This allows it to generate many domain variations to communicate with its command and control servers.

- The DGA algorithm uses a 15-bit seed value derived from the</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ro6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Ro6bi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-16" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rombi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rombi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rombi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/tor-all-the-things/25244568"><span class="sr-only">TOR... ALL THE THINGS</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:16" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">TOR... ALL THE THINGS</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save TOR... ALL THE THINGS for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mombi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mombi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mombi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mombi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mombi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Tortilla is a free and open-source tool for Windows designed to transparently route all TCP and DNS traffic through the Tor network, preventing any internet traffic that bypasses Tor. It does not require additional hardware or virtual machines and establishes strong protections against malware circumventing the Tor tunnel. The tool is easy to install and operate, making it user-friendly and effective for maintaining privacy online.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rombi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rombi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-17" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rp6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rp6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rp6bi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike/end-toend-analysis-of-a-domain-generating-algorithm-malware-family-whitepaper"><span class="sr-only">End-to-End Analysis of a Domain Generating Algorithm Malware Family Whitepaper</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:17" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV Generating Algorithm Malware Family Whitepaper</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save End-to-End Analysis of a Domain Generating Algorithm Malware Family Whitepaper for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mp6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mp6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mp6bi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mp6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mp6bi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document provides an overview of domain generating algorithms (DGAs) used by malware to dynamically determine remote server addresses and evade detection. It details the analysis performed on a malware family submitted to CrowdStrike, including deobfuscating the binary, analyzing its DGA and network functionality, sinkholing domains, and investigating the malware author. The family has been active for at least six years and infects thousands of devices.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rp6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rp6bi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rpmbi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rpmbi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rpmbi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/tor-all-the-things-whitepaper/25207431"><span class="sr-only">TOR... ALL THE THINGS Whitepaper</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:18" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">TOR... ALL THE THINGS Whitepaper</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save TOR... ALL THE THINGS Whitepaper for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mpmbi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mpmbi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mpmbi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mpmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mpmbi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document introduces Tortilla, software designed to allow security researchers to safely and anonymously interact with hostile servers and actors online. It discusses how traditional malware research was more passive, but now requires actively monitoring adversary infrastructure. The Tor network and Tor Browser Bundle are described as existing solutions for anonymity, but they have limitations like only supporting the Firefox browser and not plugins. Tortilla aims to address these issues by providing a more robust anonymity solution.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rpmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rpmbi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-19" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rq6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rq6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rq6bi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" Presence of Bootkits</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:19" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">I/O, You Own: Regaining Control of Your Disk in the Presence of Bootkits</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save I/O, You Own: Regaining Control of Your Disk in the Presence of Bootkits for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mq6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mq6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mq6bi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mq6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mq6bi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses a technique for regaining control of a disk in the presence of a bootkit by leveraging the crash dump stack in Windows. It provides background on the crash dump stack and how it differs from the normal I/O path. It then describes how identifying and calling the crash dump port and miniport drivers allows sending I/O requests outside of the normal path to bypass bootkit filters and read/write directly to disk. The document concludes with an overview of how this technique can be demonstrated against the TDL4 bootkit.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rq6bi7d6:" popover="auto" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rimci7d6:" popovertarget=":Rimci7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rimci7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" 2025</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">OpenACC and Open Hackathons Monthly Highlights June aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save OpenACC and Open Hackathons Monthly Highlights June 2025 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mimci7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mimci7d6:" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/OpenACCorg">OpenACC</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The OpenACC organization focuses on enhancing parallel computing skills and advancing interoperability in scientific applications through hackathons and training. The upcoming 2025 Open Accelerated Computing Summit (OACS) aims to explore the convergence of AI and HPC in scientific computing and foster knowledge sharing. This year&#x27;s OACS welcomes talk submissions from a variety of topics, from Using Standard Language Parallelism to Computer Vision Applications. The document also highlights several open hackathons, a call to apply for NVIDIA Academic Grant Program and resources for optimizing scientific applications using OpenACC directives.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rimci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rimci7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-5" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rj6ci7d6:" popovertarget=":Rj6ci7d6:" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/key-requirements-to-successfully-implement-generative-ai-in-edge-devices-optimized-mapping-to-the-enhanced-npx6-neural-processing-unit-ip-a-presentation-from-synopsys/280515183"><span class="sr-only">“Key Requirements to Successfully Implement Generative AI in Edge Devices—Opt...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:5" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">“Key Requirements to Successfully Implement Generative AI in Edge Devices—Opt...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save “Key Requirements to Successfully Implement Generative AI in Edge Devices—Opt... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mj6ci7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mj6ci7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mj6ci7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mj6ci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mj6ci7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/embeddedvision">Edge AI and Vision Alliance</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">For the full video of this presentation, please visit: https://www.edge-ai-vision.com/2025/06/key-requirements-to-successfully-implement-generative-ai-in-edge-devices-optimized-mapping-to-the-enhanced-npx6-neural-processing-unit-ip-a-presentation-from-synopsys/

Gordon Cooper, Principal Product Manager at Synopsys, presents the “Key Requirements to Successfully Implement Generative AI in Edge Devices—Optimized Mapping to the Enhanced NPX6 Neural Processing Unit IP” tutorial at the May 2025 Embedded Vision Summit.

In this talk, Cooper discusses emerging trends in generative AI for edge devices and the key role of transformer-based neural networks. He reviews the distinct attributes of transformers, their advantages over conventional convolutional neural networks and how they enable generative AI.

Cooper then covers key requirements that must be met for neural processing units (NPU) to support transformers and generative AI in edge device applications. He uses transformer-based generative AI examples to illustrate the efficient mapping of these workloads onto the enhanced Synopsys ARC NPX NPU IP family.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rj6ci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rj6ci7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-6" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rjmci7d6:" popovertarget=":Rjmci7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rjmci7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bridging-the-divide-a-conversation-on-tariffs-today-in-the-book-industry-tech-forum-2025/280368215"><span class="sr-only">Bridging the divide: A conversation on tariffs today in the book industry - T...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:6" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Bridging the divide: A conversation on tariffs today in the book industry - SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Russia is one of the most aggressive nations when it comes to state coordinated cyberattacks — and Ukraine has been at the center of their crosshairs for 3 years. This report, provided the State Service of Special Communications and Information Protection of Ukraine contains an incredible amount of cybersecurity insights, showcasing the coordinated aggressive cyberwarfare campaigns of Russia against Ukraine.

It brings to the forefront that understanding your adversary, especially an aggressive nation state, is important for cyber defense. Knowing their motivations, capabilities, and tactics becomes an advantage when allocating resources for maximum impact.

Intelligence shows Russia is on a cyber rampage, leveraging FSB, SVR, and GRU resources to professionally target Ukraine’s critical infrastructures, military, and international diplomacy support efforts.

The number of total incidents against Ukraine, originating from Russia, has steadily increased from 1350 in 2021 to 4315 in 2024, but the number of actual critical incidents has been managed down from a high of 1048 in 2022 to a mere 59 in 2024 — showcasing how the rapid detection and response to cyberattacks has been impacted by Ukraine’s improved cyber resilience.

Even against a much larger adversary, Ukraine is showcasing outstanding cybersecurity, enabled by strong strategies and sound tactics. There are lessons to learn for any enterprise that could potentially be targeted by aggressive nation states.

3D BIM Models Using a 3D Solids Modeling Wor...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Integration of Utility Data into 3D BIM Models Using a 3D Solids Modeling Wor... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mnmci7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mnmci7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mnmci7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/SafeSoftware">Safe Software</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Jacobs has developed a 3D utility solids modelling workflow to improve the integration of utility data into 3D Building Information Modeling (BIM) environments. This workflow, a collaborative effort between the New Zealand Geospatial Team and the Australian Data Capture Team, employs FME to convert 2D utility data into detailed 3D representations, supporting enhanced spatial analysis and clash detection.

To enable the automation of this process, Jacobs has also developed a survey data standard that standardizes the capture of existing utilities. This standard ensures consistency in data collection, forming the foundation for the subsequent automated validation and modelling steps. The workflow begins with the acquisition of utility survey data, including attributes such as location, depth, diameter, and material of utility assets like pipes and manholes. This data is validated through a custom-built tool that ensures completeness and logical consistency, including checks for proper connectivity between network components. Following validation, the data is processed using an automated modelling tool to generate 3D solids from 2D geometric representations. These solids are then integrated into BIM models to facilitate compatibility with 3D workflows and enable detailed spatial analyses.

The workflow contributes to improved spatial understanding by visualizing the relationships between utilities and other infrastructure elements. The automation of validation and modeling processes ensures consistent and accurate outputs, minimizing errors and increasing workflow efficiency.

This methodology highlights the application of FME in addressing challenges associated with geospatial data transformation and demonstrates its utility in enhancing data integration within BIM frameworks. By enabling accurate 3D representation of utility networks, the workflow supports improved design collaboration and decision-making in complex infrastructure projects</span></div></div><div class="" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">DC Inverter Air Conditioners are revolutionizing the cooling industry by delivering affordable,
energy-efficient, and environmentally sustainable climate control solutions. Unlike conventional 
fixed-speed air conditioners, DC inverter systems operate with variable-speed compressors that 
modulate cooling output based on demand, significantly reducing energy consumption and 
extending the lifespan of the appliance.
These systems are critical in reducing electricity usage, lowering greenhouse gas emissions, and 
promoting eco-friendly technologies in residential and commercial sectors. With advancements in
compressor control, refrigerant efficiency, and smart energy management, DC inverter air conditioners 
have become a benchmark in sustainable climate control solutions</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rq6ci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" Who’s Targeting You and Why?

ADAM MEYERS |

of cyber security industry experience

ranging from wireless, pen testing, IR, and malware analysis

 </li></div><div><li>4. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#4">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

4

 </li></div><div><li>5. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#5">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries </a> are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

29

 </li></div><div><li>30. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#30">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN </a> SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Adversary-Centric

1

INTELLIGENCE

Understand the adversaries targeting your
Vertical | Company | Geo-Location | Customers

2

Build appropriate defenses to counter/detect
these adversaries

3

Perform other security practices from an
Adversary-centric perspective
Pen Testing (Red Team)
Security Operations Brieﬁngs
Log Review

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

30

 </li></div><div><li>31. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#31">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN </a> SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Making it Actionable

1
ACTIONALIZING INTELLIGENCE

Intelligence is diﬃcult to consume
Lots of information to keep straight
New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

2

Security Operations need to change shis &amp; people

3

Actionable Intelligence

Pass down can’t possibly occur with all indicators

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

31

 </li></div><div><li>32. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-casts-monthly-you-have-an-adversary-problem/27262315#32">@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversary </a> Microsite
COMING SOON

This workflow, a collaborative effort between the New Zealand Geospatial Team and the Australian Data Capture Team, employs FME to convert 2D utility data into detailed 3D representations, supporting enhanced spatial analysis and clash detection.\r\n\r\nTo enable the automation of this process, Jacobs has also developed a survey data standard that standardizes the capture of existing utilities. This standard ensures consistency in data collection, forming the foundation for the subsequent automated validation and modelling steps. The workflow begins with the acquisition of utility survey data, including attributes such as location, depth, diameter, and material of utility assets like pipes and manholes. This data is validated through a custom-built tool that ensures completeness and logical consistency, including checks for proper connectivity between network components. Following validation, the data is processed using an automated modelling tool to generate 3D solids from 2D geometric representations. These solids are then integrated into BIM models to facilitate compatibility with 3D workflows and enable detailed spatial analyses.\r\n\r\nThe workflow contributes to improved spatial understanding by visualizing the relationships between utilities and other infrastructure elements.
